===Higher education=== The [[Higher Education Statistics Agency]] gathers and publishes annual statistics relating to the higher qualifications awarded in the UK. The Students and Qualifiers data sets indicate that the percentage of "GOOD" first degree classifications have increased annually since 1995. For example, 7% of all first-degree students who graduated in the academic year 1995/96 achieved first class honours; by 2008/09 this had risen to 14%.<ref name="dailymailarticlefirstclassdegrees">{{cite news | work = [[The Daily Mail]] | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1243237/Number-students-awarded-class-degree-doubles-12-years-seven.html | title = Number of students awarded first class degree doubles in 12 years to one in seven | date = 14 January 2010 | accessdate = 17 April 2012 | location=London | first=Cher | last=Thornhill }}</ref><ref name="HESAfreeonlinedatatables">{{cite web | url=http://www.hesa.ac.uk/index.php/content/view/1973/239/ | title=HESA Free Online Data Tables | publisher=Higher Education Statistics Agency | accessdate=17 April 2012}}</ref>
Between 1995 and 2011, the proportion of upper second class honours awarded for first degree courses increased from 40.42% to 48.38%, whilst lower second class honours dropped from 34.97% to 28.9%. The number of third class honours, "ordinary" (i.e. pass), and unclassified awards dropped substantially during the same period. During this time, the total number of first degrees awarded in the UK increased by 56%, from 212,000 to 331,000.<ref name="HESAfreeonlinedatatables" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stopgradeinflation.ie/Grade_Inflation_in_the_University_Sector.pdf|title=Grade Inflation in Irish Universities (1994 – 2004) by Martin O’Grady and Brendan Guilfoyle|publisher=|access-date=2012-09-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130810065209/http://www.stopgradeinflation.ie/Grade_Inflation_in_the_University_Sector.pdf|archive-date=2013-08-10|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
Grade inflation in UK universities appears to be caused by administrators wishing to improve their league table standings, a desire to attract non-European students who can be charged full fees, academics who fear receiving unfavourable [[course evaluation]]s from students, the breakdown of the external examiner system, and a growing indifference towards academic dishonesty and plagiarism.<ref>{{cite news| last =Alderman| first =Geoffrey| title =Why university standards have fallen| newspaper =The Guardian| date =10 March 2010| url =https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/mar/10/universities-standards-blair-target| accessdate = 22 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.reform.uk/publication/a-degree-of-uncertainty-an-investigation-into-grade-inflation-in-universities/ | title =A degree of uncertainty: An investigation into grade inflation in universities | last =Richmond | first =Tom | date =June 2018 | website =[[Reform (think tank)|Reform]] | publisher = | access-date =22 June 2018 | quote = }}</ref>
'''Note''': The [[New universities|doubling of institutions]] and quadrupling of student numbers, following the [[Further and Higher Education Act 1992]], makes any direct comparison of pre and post 1995 awards non trivial, if not meaningless. <br /> {| class="wikitable" |+UK: Percentages of 1st Class awards by Institution |- ! ! 1980 ! 2000 ! 2010 |- |Cambridge |13 |29.8 |23 |- |Warwick |3 |10.8 |23 |- |Exeter |4 |10.5 |19 |- |St. Andrews | 7 | 11.7 | 20 |} Source: [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/universityeducation/9011098/Warning-over-grade-inflation-as-first-class-degrees-double.html],[http://specials.ft.com/universities2001/FT3HLLAN6LC.html]
{| class="wikitable" |+UK: Percentages of good Honours awards<br>(1st and upper 2nd) by Institution |- ! ! 1983–4 ! 1984–5 ! 2006 ! 2008 ! 2012 |- | Cambridge |57.2 |49.3 |84 |85 |87 |- | Warwick |34 |42 |79 |76 |81 |- |Exeter |41 |45.3 |75 |80 |83 |- |Robert Gordon |9 |12 |53 |54 |55 |} Source: Sunday Times Good University Guide, 1983–4 (1st Ed), 1984–5 (2nd Ed), 2006, 2008, 2012
{| class="wikitable" |+UK: First degree awards |- !Awards by class !First (1) !%'age !Upper Second (2.1) !%'age !Undivided + Lower Second (2.2) !%'age |- ! 1994<ref name="UK1993">{{Citation | last = Smith | first = Jeremy | title = Determinants of degree performance in the UK universities: a statistical analysis of the 1993 cohort (63, 1 0305-9049) | publisher = Oxford Bulletin of Economics and Statistics | page = 33 | location = Warwick | date = 2001 | url = http://www.warwick.ac.uk/go/robinnaylor/publications/obes2001.pdf | accessdate = <!-----18 March 2014----->}}</ref> ||~7937||8.4 ||~38077||40.3 ||~26361||27.9 |- ! 1995 ||16687||7.04 ||95824 ||40.42 ||82898 ||34.97 |- ! 1996 ||17352||6.86||103049||40.76||89533||35.41 |- ! 1997 ||18154||7.03||105538||40.87||91534||35.45 |- ! 1998 ||19613||7.44||109409||41.50||90805||34.44 |- ! 1999 ||20852||8.37||112504||45.14||94036||37.73 |- ! 2000 ||21920||8.66||114660||45.31||91770||36.26 |- ! 2001 ||24095||8.77||118465||43.14||89750||32.68 |- ! 2002 ||26455||9.67||121240||44.31||86650||31.67 |- ! 2003 ||28635||10.96||123795||47.37||88260||33.77 |- ! 2004 ||30175||11.2||127935||47.5||90470||33.59 |- ! 2005 ||32465||11.59||132770||47.4||92605||33.06 |- ! 2006 ||34825||12.04||137235||47.46||94265||32.6 |- ! 2007 ||40260||12.52||149805||46.59||103340||32.14 |- ! 2008 ||41150||13.34||148265||48.05||95145||30.84 |- ! 2009 ||43125||13.99||148360||48.12||93030||30.17 |- !2010 ||46830||14.4||156950||48.26||96970||29.82 |- ! 2011 ||53210||15.5||166095||48.38||99210||28.9 |- ! 2012 ||61605||15.76||178425||45.63||100310||25.66 |- ! 2013 ||69625||17.24||187365||46.40||98145||24.30 |- ! 2014 ||79435||18.83||198405||47.02||96030||22.76 |}
Source: [http://www.hesa.ac.uk/index.php/content/view/1973/239/ Higher Education Statistics Agency][http://discover.ukdataservice.ac.uk/catalogue/?sn=3456&type=Data%20catalogue Universities' Statistical Record, 1972/73-1993/94 : Undergraduate Records]
====UK first degrees by awards from 1993/4 to 2013/14====
{{ #invoke:Chart | bar chart | stack = 1 | group 1 = 7937 : 16687 : 17352: 18154 : 19613 : 20852 : 21920 : 24095 : 26455 : 28635 : 30175 : 32465 : 34825 : 40260 : 41150 : 43125 : 46830 : 53210 : 61605 : 69625 : 79435 | group 2 = 38077 : 95824 : 103049 : 105538 : 109409 : 112504 : 114660 : 118465 : 121240 : 123795 : 127935 : 132770 : 137235 : 149805 : 148265 : 148360 : 156950 : 166095 : 178425 : 187365 : 198405 | group 3 = 26361 : 82898 : 89533 : 91534 : 90805 : 94036 : 91770 : 89750 : 86650 : 88260 : 90470 : 92605 : 94265 : 103340 : 95145 : 93030 : 96970 : 99210 : 100310 : 98145 : 96030 | group 4 = 9411 : 13770 : 13694 : 22877 : 22186 : 21824 : 21160 : 21150 : 19625 : 20670 : 20785 : 22285 : 22850 : 23195 : 23990 : 23800 : 24455 : 24825 : 23935 : 23470 : 21915 | group 5 = 12680 : 27874 : 29203 : 20125 : 19788 : 19210 : 20810 : 19205 : 20475 : 21010 : 22725 : 26235 : 26815 : 27880 : 26255 : 25325 : 25540 : 25535 : 26715 : 24920 : 26000 | colors = red : blue : green : orange : purple | x legends = : 1995 : : : : : 2000 : : : : : 2005 : : : : : 2010 : : : : | width = 900 | group names = 1st awards: 2.1 awards: 2.2 awards: 3rd + Pass awards : unclassified | units suffix = _degrees awarded }}
====UK first degrees by classification from 1993/4 to 2013/14==== <br /> {{ #invoke:Chart | bar chart | stack = 1 | group 1 = 8.4 : 7.02 : 6.86 : 7.03 : 7.44 : 7.77 : 8.11 : 8.84 : 9.64 : 10.14 : 10.33 : 10.60 : 11.02 : 11.48 : 12.29 : 12.92 : 13.35 : 14.42 : 15.76 : 17.24 : 18.83 | group 2 = 40.33 : 40.30 : 40.76 : 40.87 : 41.50 : 41.91 : 42.42 : 43.45 : 44.18 : 43.84 : 43.80 : 43.34 : 43.43 : 43.46 : 44.27 : 44.46 : 44.73 : 45.01 : 45.63 : 46.40 : 47.03 | group 3 = 27.9 : 34.86 : 35.41 : 35.45 : 34.44 : 35.03 : 33.95 : 32.92 : 31.57 : 31.26 : 30.97 : 30.23 : 29.83 : 29.07 : 28.41 : 27.88 : 27.64 : 26.89 : 25.66 : 24.31 : 22.76 | group 4 = 9.96 : 5.79 : 5.42 : 8.86 : 8.42 : 8.13 : 7.83 : 7.76 : 7.15 : 7.32 : 7.12 : 7.27 : 7.23 : 7.27 : 7.16 : 7.13 : 6.97 : 6.73 : 6.12 : 5.81 : 5.19 | group 5 = 13.42 : 11.72 : 11.55 : 7.79 : 7.51 : 7.16 : 7.70 : 7.04 : 7.46 : 7.44 : 7.78 : 8.56 : 8.49 : 8.73 : 7.84 : 7.59 : 7.28 : 6.92 : 6.83 : 6.17 : 6.16 | colors = green : yellow : orange : red : purple | x legends = : 1995 : : : : : 2000 : : : : : 2005 : : : : : 2010 : : : : | width = 900 | group names = 1st: 2.1: 2.2: 3rd + Pass: Unclassified | units suffix = _% degrees awarded }}
==In France== Between 2005 and 2016 the proportion of students receiving an honor in the general [[baccalauréat]] doubled.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.euronews.com/2017/07/05/what-is-the-bac | title =What is the bac? | last = | first = | date =5 July 2017 | website =Euronews | publisher = | access-date =12 July 2017 | quote = }}</ref>
==In India== In [[Central Board of Secondary Education|CBSE]], a 95 per cent aggregate is 21 times as prevalent today as it was in 2004, and a 90 per cent close to nine times as prevalent. In the [[Council for the Indian School Certificate Examinations|ISC Board]], a 95 per cent is almost twice as prevalent today as it was in 2012. CBSE called a meeting of all 40 school boards early in 2017 to urge them to discontinue “artificial spiking of marks”. CBSE decided to lead by example and promised not to inflate its results. But although the 2017 results have seen a small correction, the board has clearly not discarded the practice completely. Almost 6.5 per cent of mathematics examinees in 2017 scored 95 or more — 10 times higher than in 2004 — and almost 6 per cent of physics examinees scored 95 or more, 35 times more than in 2004.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://indianexpress.com/article/education/when-90-per-cent-comes-too-easy-cbse-board-exam-results-4689291/ | title =When 90% comes too easy in CBSE exams | last =Chopra | first =Ritika | date =6 June 2017 | website =Indian Express | publisher = | access-date =11 October 2017 | quote = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.deccanchronicle.com/opinion/op-ed/110717/inflated-marks-100-and-still-galloping.html | title =Inflated marks: 100% and still galloping... | last =Kar | first =Devi | date =11 July 2017 | website =Deccan Chronicle | publisher = | access-date =11 October 2017 | quote =Board examination results have lost their credibility in India. }}</ref>
==Possible problems== *It reduces the incentive for bright students to [[excellence|excel]], since mediocre work increasingly qualifies for top grades. *It undermines the [[corrective feedback]] function of grading.<ref>{{cite web| last =Leef| first =George| title =Grade Inflation Eats Away at the Meaning of College| website =Foundation for Economic Education| date =21 April 2016| url =https://fee.org/articles/grade-inflation-eats-away-at-the-meaning-of-college/| accessdate = 7 July 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Ramey | first =Gregory | title =Phony grades: A threat to your student's mental health? | newspaper =The News-Review | location =Roseburg, Oregon | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =14 March 2017 | url =http://www.nrtoday.com/phony-grades-a-threat-to-your-student-s-mental-health/article_0dc54456-30c2-5cce-b049-b370b433a4ae.html | access-date =21 March 2017 }}</ref> *It is not uniform between schools. This places students in more stringently graded schools and departments at an unfair disadvantage, unless employers take into account a [[College and university rankings|school's ranking]]. *It is not uniform among disciplines. *It makes it more difficult to compare students who took their exams at different times. *Prospective employers must rely on indicators other than grades, such as [[internship]]s and [[work experience]], in order to gauge a graduate's [[Skill|skill level]] and [[Attitude (psychology)|attitude]].<ref>{{cite web | url =https://chronicle.com/items/biz/pdf/Employers%20Survey.pdf | title =The Role of Higher Education in Career Development: Employer Perceptions | last =Thompson | first =Derek | date =December 2012 | website =[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]] | publisher = | access-date =30 May 2016 | quote = }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last =Yorke| first =Harry| title =University grade inflation warning as number of students obtaining first class degrees triples in less than two decades| newspaper =Telegraph| date =12 January 2017| url =https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/2017/01/12/one-four-students-now-obtain-first-class-degrees-employers-voice/| accessdate = 14 January 2017}}</ref>
===Arguments against taking action on grade inflation=== *Higher grades at some schools may reflect better performance than others (although with no national standard, there can be no way to compare one school to another by grades). *Although grade inflation does not evenly distribute through departments, it is arguable due to the subjective nature of grades, that interdepartmental grading practices were not equal in the first place (e.g. how is one supposed to determine the equivalent grade for an English course to an ''A'' grade in Physics?) *It can motivate students of average ability to invest in an academic degree, instead of learning a [[skilled trade]] at a [[vocational school]]. *The US system still allows the brightest students to excel by offering courses with [[Honors student|honors options]] as well as awarding [[valedictorian]]s.
===Arguments against its existence=== *In 1995, Clifford Adelman, a senior research analyst for the U.S. Department of Education, reviewed student transcripts from more than 3,000 universities and reported that student grades had actually declined slightly over the prior 20 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ericdigests.org/2005-1/grade.htm|title=Grade Inflation in Higher Education|publisher= ERIC Digest}}</ref> *A report issued by the National Center for Education Statistics surveyed all 16.5 million undergraduate students in the USA in the year 1999–2000. The study concluded that 28.9% of graduates received mostly ''C'' grades or lower, while only 14.5% received mostly ''A'' grades.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://nces.ed.gov/pubs2002/2002168.PDF|title=Profile of Undergraduates in U.S. Postsecondary Institutions: 1999–2000|publisher=U.S. Department of Education. National Center for Education Statistics|date=July 2002|author=Laura Horn|author2=Katharin Peter|author3=Kathryn Rooney|author4=Andrew G. Malizio|location=Washington, DC}}</ref> *In 2004, [[Alfie Kohn]] argued that "it has never been shown ... that those higher grades are undeserved".<ref name="Arenson 2004">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/04/18/weekinreview/is-it-grade-inflation-or-are-students-just-smarter.html|title=Is It Grade Inflation, or Are Students Just Smarter?|first=|date=18 April 2004|website=|publisher=|newspaper=The New York Times|author=Arenson, Karen W.|accessdate=6 December 2015}}</ref>
==Ratings inflation== Grade inflation is a specific instance of a broader phenomena of ratings or reputation inflation where rating decisions are made by individuals. This has been occurring in peer-to-peer services such as [[Uber]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Griswold|first1=Alison|title=Good luck leaving your Uber driver less than five stars|url=https://qz.com/1244155/good-luck-leaving-your-uber-driver-less-than-five-stars/|accessdate=5 April 2018|work=[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]]|date=5 April 2018}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Academic inflation]] *[[Affirmative action]] *[[Class rank]] *[[Dumbing down]] *[[Flynn effect]] *[[Latin honors]] *[[Political correctness]] *[[Valedictorian]], the highest ranking graduate *[[Salutatorian]], typically the second highest ranking graduate
==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Refbegin}} * {{ Citation | first1 = Stuart | last1 = Rojstaczer | first2 = Christopher | last2 = Healy | title = Grading in American Colleges and Universities | date = 2010-03-04 | journal = Teachers College Record | url = http://www.tcrecord.org/Content.asp?ContentID=15928 | accessdate = 2010-04-19 | postscript = [http://www.gradeinflation.com/tcr2010grading.pdf copy available].}} {{Refend}}
==External links== {{Wiktionary}} * [http://www.gradeinflation.com Grade Inflation At American Colleges and Universities] <!--** [https://web.archive.org/web/20090418151232/http://media.www.dukechronicle.com/media/storage/paper884/news/2009/03/17/News/Gpas-Have.Steadily.Risen.Over.Decades-3673776.shtml GPAs have risen steadily over decades: Since 1960, average Duke GPA has increased 1 point]--> <!--** [[Daily Princetonian]]: [https://web.archive.org/web/20060818070600/http://www.dailyprincetonian.com/features/index.jsp?id=39 Series on Grade Deflation] --> * [[Alfie Kohn]]: [http://www.alfiekohn.org/teaching/gi.htm The Dangerous Myth of Grade Inflation] * Sita Slavov: [https://www.usnews.com/opinion/blogs/economic-intelligence/2013/12/26/why-college-grade-inflation-is-a-real-problem-and-how-to-fix-it How to Fix College Grade Inflation: Inflated grades are a serious problem, but there are ways to fix them.] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20041015060240/http://alfiekohn.org/teaching/gisources.htm Grade Inflation Sources] <!--* [http://chronicle.com/free/v47/i30/30b02401.htm Grade Inflation: It's Time to Face the Facts] Requires subscription --> * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060920233617/http://www.ent.ohiou.edu/~manhire/grade/2004-22_Final.pdf Grade Inflation, Ethics and Engineering Education] * [http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2006/07/26/scipipeline So that is why they are leaving (the sciences) from Inside Higher Ed] * [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/06/02/AR2005060201593_pf.html A's for Everyone!] (''The Washington Post'' article written by [[Alicia Shepard]]) * [http://ssrn.com/abstract=531623 Nominal GPA and Real GPA: A Simple Adjustment that Compensates for Grade Inflation] * [http://ssrn.com/abstract=2405629 Real GPA and Real SET: Two Antidotes to Greed, Sloth, and Cowardice in the College Classroom]

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | logo = GMAC LOGO POS SML RGB.jpg | type = | key_people = Sangeet Chowfla <small>(President & Chief Executive)</small> | footnotes = | name = Graduate Management Admission Council | founded_date = 1953 | founder = | location = [[Reston, Virginia]] | origins = | area_served = Worldwide | focus = Education, testing | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.gmac.com}} | dissolved = }}
The '''Graduate Management Admission Council''' ('''GMAC''') is an international non-profit organization of business schools that provides products and services to academic institutions and prospective graduate management education students. The organization owns the [[Graduate Management Admission Test]] (GMAT), a standardized assessment that is widely used by graduate [[business studies|business administration]] programs (e.g. [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]], [[Master of Accountancy]], Master of Finance, Master of Science in Business/Management, etc.) to measure quantitative, verbal, analytical and integrated reasoning skills in applicants. GMAC also provides survey research and market analysis aimed at helping graduate management admissions professionals make informed decisions, and serves as an information source for journalists and members of the public interested in information about management education and the role it plays in the global economy.
GMAC is based in [[Reston, Virginia]]. In 2007, the organization opened an office in [[London]], its first international location.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gmac.com/gmac/newsandevents/pressroom/pressreleases/lbsofficialtoleadeuropeanoperationsofgmac.htm |title=London Business School Official to Lead European Operations of Graduate Management Education Group |accessdate=17 June 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080402102134/http://www.gmac.com/gmac/newsandevents/pressroom/pressreleases/lbsofficialtoleadeuropeanoperationsofgmac.htm |archivedate=2 April 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> GMAC also has offices based in [[Hong Kong]] and [[Gurgaon, India]].<ref>{{cite web | url= https://www.gmac.com/service/contact-us.aspx | title= GMAC Contact us and Locations| accessdate=9 April 2012 }}</ref> The Graduate Management Admission Council has 212 member schools from 22 countries, including Australia, Canada, China, France, Great Britain, India and the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.gmac.com/why-gmac/the-gmac-advantage/gmac-history-timeline.aspx| title= GMAC History | accessdate=9 April 2012 }}</ref> In 2007, the organization embarked on an effort to increase its membership outside North America.<ref>{{cite web | title= Graduate Management Admission Council Introduces New Global Executive Team | accessdate=17 June 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080402103824/http://www.gmac.com/gmac/newsandevents/pressroom/pressreleases/gmacintroducesnewglobalexecutiveteam.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2 April 2008|url= http://www.gmac.com/gmac/newsandevents/pressroom/pressreleases/gmacintroducesnewglobalexecutiveteam.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> }}</ref> GMAC is governed by a 15-member board of directors that includes representation from business schools and private industry.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.gmac.com/about-us/board-of-directors.aspx| title=Board of Directors | accessdate=9 April 2012 }}</ref>
==Products and services== {{main|Graduate Management Admission Test}} Today, the GMAT Exam is used by more than 6,000 graduate management education programs at approximately 2,100 business schools worldwide. The exam, taken more than 230,000 times per year,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.gmac.com/gmat/the-gmat-advantage/gmat-using-programs-schools.aspx | title= GMAT Accepting Universities & Schools | accessdate=5 April 2012 }}</ref> is designed as an objective predictor of how well a student will perform academically in the first year of a graduate business education program. Through the Validity Study Service (VSS), the GMAT has been shown by researchers to be a reliable predictor of academic performance in business school,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://epm.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/66/2/305 | title=Evaluating the Predictive Validity of Graduate Management Admission Test Scores | accessdate=16 June 2008 }}</ref> especially when used in combination with an applicant's undergraduate grade point average.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.gmac.com/gmat/understand-gmat-exam-scores/calibrate-student-performance.aspx | title= Calibrate Student Performance (VSS)| accessdate=9 April 2012 }}</ref> In June 2012, a new section was added to the GMAT Exam called Integrated Reasoning. This section is designed to measure a test taker's ability to evaluate information presented in new formats from multiple sources.
GMAC's other products include the Graduate Management Admission Search Service (GMASS), a searchable database of more than 350,000 GMAT Exam and mba.com registrants that admissions professionals use to search for and recruit candidates.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.gmac.com/reach-and-recruit-students/recruit-students-for-your-program/recruit-with-precision.aspx | title= Recruit with Precision (GMASS) | accessdate=9 April 2012 }}</ref> Admissions professionals can also use GMATCH, GMAC's two-day online global recruiting event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gmac.com/reach-and-recruit-students/recruit-students-for-your-program/online-recruiting-fair.aspx |title=Recruit Virtually GMATCH |accessdate=23 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130430202725/http://www.gmac.com/reach-and-recruit-students/recruit-students-for-your-program/online-recruiting-fair.aspx |archivedate=30 April 2013 |df= }}</ref>
In 2013, GMAC launched the Reflect Self-Assessment and Development Tool. It is an online assessment and self-directed, soft-skills development program. It can be used with or without a facilitator. It evaluates 10 soft skills including innovation, operational thinking, and resilience that were identified by admissions directors, corporate recruiters, and top executives as critical in the classroom and office.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.investors.com/newsfeed-marketwire/022013-141438812-the-graduate-management-admission-council-launches-reflecttm-by-gmac-powered-by-hogan-assessments.aspx?p=full | title= The Graduate Management Admission Council Launches Reflect(TM) by GMAC | accessdate=23 April 2013 }}</ref>
GMAC research includes surveys and trend analysis on graduate management education worldwide. GMAC Research includes: Research on the GMAT Exam: * '''Volume trends.''' GMAC members have access to the latest in GMAT volume trends, a monthly resource with five-year comparisons. *'''Profile of GMAT Candidates.''' The annual publication released in November offers five- and 10-year trend data on average scores and GMAT volume by demographic breakdowns. *'''Geographic Trend Reports.''' World, European, Asian, and North American Geographic Trend Report, as well as the GMAT Trends in Student Mobility, offer analyses of business school student mobility based on GMAT volume and score-sending data. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gmac.com/gmac/researchandtrends |title=GMAC Research & Trends |accessdate=17 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080629141735/http://www.gmac.com/gmac/researchandtrends |archivedate=29 June 2008 |df= }}</ref> Survey Research: *'''Global Management Education Graduate Survey.''' Survey of graduate business school students in their final year at participating business schools, a few months before graduation, expressing their opinions about their education, the value of their degrees, and what they intend to do with their degrees after graduation. *'''Corporate Recruiters Survey.''' Survey of employers examines the job market for graduate business students as well as employer needs and expectations. *'''mba.com Prospective Students Survey.''' Probes the opinions, needs, and preferences of potential graduate business students who registered on mba.com, the GMAC website for potential students as well as the portal for the GMAT exam. *'''Alumni Perspectives Survey.''' A longitudinal study of former respondents to the Global Management Education Graduate Survey. The study documents job characteristics for both the first jobs alumni held after graduation and their current jobs; tracks changes in responsibilities, promotions, and salary over time; assesses the benefits of graduate management education in retrospect; and monitors alumni educational needs. *'''2012 Application Trends Survey.''' Survey of admissions professionals provides application volume trends, applicant pool composition, recruitment strategies and marketing channels, acceptance and enrollment rates, enrollment structure, and class size.
==gmac.com resources== GMAC offers an array of professional development programs and conferences for graduate management admissions professionals, including the GMAC Annual Industry Conference, the Admissions Institute for New Professionals, and an annual Leadership Conference, as well as Global Symposia and Webinars.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.gmac.com/professional-development-and-careers/pd-opportunities.aspx | title= Professional Development Opportunities | accessdate= 9 April 2012 }}</ref> The gmac.com website serves as the informational hub for all GMAC webinars for admissions professionals and students. The site also includes information on upcoming products and research findings related to graduate management education and the student pipeline.
==mba.com: website== GMAC owns mba.com, which provides information on a wide range of topics for prospective graduate management students, including GMAT exam registration, program options, financial aid opportunities, career choices, and alumni profiles. The website also features GMAT study products, available through an online store, as well as free GMAT preparation software, available to registrants of mba.com. The website also serves as the portal for scheduling GMAT exam appointments at one of the more than 600 test centers located in 114 countries worldwide.
== NMAT == NMAT], also known as '''[[SVKM's NMIMS|NMIMS]] Management Admission Test''' which is conducted by GMAC for admission to top B schools of India. 23 top institutes accepts NMAT score. [https://www.mbarendezvous.com/nmat/nmat-participating-institutes/ NMAT by GMAC™ 2018 Participating Institutes].
==Giving back== GMAC is committed to investing in strategic philanthropic initiatives to benefit business and management education globally. Established in 2008, the GMAC Management Education for Tomorrow Fund (MET Fund) is a $10 million commitment that benefits graduate management students, faculty and institutions. The Ideas to Innovation Challenge (i2i) was established in 2011 and featured the submission of 650 ideas to improve graduate management education. Of these 650 ideas, 20 were chosen to be implemented through proposals from schools and other educational institutions. On April 17, 2012, the MET Fund announced US$7.1 million in grants to 12 schools and organizations that submitted the most creative implementation plans.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.gmac.com/why-gmac/giving-back.aspx | title=Giving Back | accessdate=9 April 2012 }}</ref>
In 2005, GMAC launched TeamMBA in 2005, a global initiative for community service by students in graduate management programs. Since launching TeamMBA, hundreds of students, staff, and faculty from scores of schools have donated thousands of volunteer hours and raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for charities and community organizations.
==See also== * [[Master of Accountancy]] * [[Master of Finance]] * [[Master of Business Administration]] * [[Standardized Test]]

{{DEFAULTSORT:Graduate Management Admission Council}} [[Category:Standardized tests]] [[Category:Companies based in Reston, Virginia]] [[Category:Business schools]] [[Category:1953 establishments in the United States]]

'''Green Schools Alliance''' ('''GSA''') is an effort by primary and secondary schools worldwide to address [[climate change]] and [[Conservation (ethic)|conservation]] challenges by creating a [[peer-to-peer]] network of member schools committed to reducing their [[greenhouse gas]] emissions and accelerating the implementation of sustainable solutions.
GSA member schools share and implement [[sustainability]] [[best practices]] and promote connections between schools, communities, and the environments that sustain them. GSA does this by creating peer-to-peer forums, exchanging resources, offering original programs and [[curriculum]], and connecting youth to nature.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mounce Stancil|first1=Joanna|title=Student Climate and Conservation Congress: Bright Young Minds|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/blogs/student-climate-and-conservation-congress-bright-young-minds|website=U.S.Forest Service|accessdate=August 26, 2015}}</ref> The sustainability coordinators that participate in the network are composed of faculty, staff, students, administrators, and other school decision makers.
==History== The GSA was formed in October 2007 as a result of [[Mayor of New York City]] [[Michael Bloomberg]]’s [[PlaNYC]] and related challenge to all NYC facilities to reduce carbon emissions by 30% by 2050, with support from the NYC Mayor's Office of Long-Term Planning and Sustainability, [[New York State Energy Research and Development Authority]] (NYSERDA), [[Clinton Foundation|Clinton Climate Initiative]] (CCI), [[Consolidated Edison]], [[National Association of Independent Schools]] (NAIS) and National Business Officers Association (NBOA).
The Allen-Stevenson School in NYC hosted the first GSA planning session that convened schools to address [[climate change]] and "what schools can do about it", and review the GSA Commitment. With additional guidance from the [[American College & University Presidents' Climate Commitment]] (ACUPCC), Second Nature and AASHE, the GSA primary and secondary school climate dommitment was further refined. In November 2007, with a signatory group of 40 schools, the GSA was launched to the public at the [[US Green Building Council]] annual GreenBuild Conference when President [[Bill Clinton]] highlighted the GSA in his keynote speech. It is currently listed as one of the organizations committed to the Climate Education and Literacy Initiative launched by the White House [[Office of Science and Technology Policy]] (OSTP)<ref>{{cite news|last=Bidwell|first=Allie|title=Obama Wants Kids to Learn About Global Warming.Read more: The administration wants students and teachers to toe the line on climate change|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/12/03/obama-administration-to-launch-global-warming-education-initiative/|newspaper=U.S. News & World Report|accessdate=3 December 2014|date=5 December 2014}}</ref>
==Green Schools Alliance today== The [[Environmental groups and resources serving K–12 schools|501c3 nonprofit organization]] now connects more than 9,000 schools<ref>{{cite news|last=Kaye|first=Leon|title=Mayor Bloomberg Turns on NYC’s First Wind Turbine at a City School|url=http://inhabitat.com/nyc/mayor-bloomberg-turns-on-nycs-first-wind-turbine-at-a-city-school/|accessdate=28 April 2014|newspaper=Inhabitat New York City|date=14 June 2012}}</ref>, districts,<ref>{{cite news|last=New York City Department of Education|title=Schools Facilities CEO John Shea, City Sustainability Deputy Director Adam Freed and Actor Matthew Modine Call on Schools to Reduce Energy Consumption by Joining the Green Cup Challenge|url=http://schools.nyc.gov/Offices/mediarelations/NewsandSpeeches/2009-2010/greencup011310.htm|accessdate=29 April 2014|newspaper=Highbeam.com|date=13 January 2010}}</ref> and organizations worldwide, representing more than 5 million students in 48 U.S. states, the District of Columbia, and 88 countries. Schools are participating individually or and as entire school districts<ref>{{cite news|last=Lauren|first=Roth|title=Orange schools recognize Earth Day with green initiatives|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/features/blogs/school-zone/os-orange-schools-earth-day-20140421,0,7074383.post?track=rss|accessdate=28 April 2014|newspaper=Orlando Sentinel|date=22 April 2014}}</ref> to share sustainability best practices and reduce their environmental footprint.<ref>{{cite news|last=Perryfirst=Katy|title=How schools across the US united to save 2.5M pounds of CO2|url=http://www.greenbiz.com/blog/2013/05/03/how-schools-across-us-united-save-25m-pounds-co2|accessdate=9 May 2015|newspaper=Greenbiz.com|date=3 May 2013}}</ref> In January 2016, 21 school districts<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://blog.ed.gov/2016/01/large-school-districts-come-together-to-prioritize-sustainability/|title=Large School Districts Come Together to Prioritize Sustainability - ED.gov Blog|date=2016-01-26|work=ED.gov Blog|access-date=2017-07-12|language=en-US}}</ref> formed the Green Schools Alliance District Collaborative<ref>{{cite web|title=An alliance of superheroes from schools seek green strategies (podcast)|url=http://students.lps.org/post/detail.cfm?id=10568|website=Lincoln Public Schools}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>which will harness the collective power of schools to support greener, more efficient solutions. These districts will build and share best practices, leverage their combined purchasing power to increase access to sustainable alternatives, promote market transformation, and influence policy decisions. Charter members of the District Collaborative affect the lives of 3.6 million children in 5,726 schools with more than 550 million square feet of building area. {{ad|date=July 2018}} Membership to the GSA's online community is free. Schools and districts can also pledge the Sustainability Leadership where princials, heads of school, and superintendents pledge to take action in these areas: Reduce Our Climate & Ecological Impact, Educate & Engage Our Community, and Transform Our Culture.
==Programs== GSA programs integrate education and action and aggregate and quantify progress. Using the building and campus as a teaching tool, students work alongside faculty and staff on projects from recycling, [[weatherization|weatherizing]], conducting energy audits, changing lights and replacing old boilers to improving science and technology education, restoring wetlands and planting green roofs. Best practices ripple outward from schools to families, to the workplace. GSA programs include: * Green Cup Challenge<ref>{{cite web|last=Peter|first=Gow|title=Public Purpose: Environmentalism in Independent Schools--and Others!|url=http://blogs.edweek.org/edweek/independent_schools/2013/08/public_purpose_environmentalism_in_independent_schoolsand_others.html|publisher=Education Week|accessdate=21 April 2014|date=9 August 2013}}</ref> * Student Climate & Conservation Corps (Sc3)<ref>{{cite news|last=Watson|first=Rob|title=Radical Confidence in the Next Green Generation|url=http://www.greenbiz.com/blog/2011/06/30/radical-confidence-next-green-generation|accessdate=29 April 2014|newspaper=Greenbiz.com|date=30 June 2011}}</ref> * GSA Online Community * GSA Sustainability Leadership Commitment * GSA Purchasing Solution * OnAir Schools * protostar * Sustainability Tracking and Roadmap Tool (START)
==See also== * [[Environmental groups and resources serving K–12 schools]]

{{Infobox person | pre-nominals = | name = Hansa Yogendra | post-nominals = | image = Hansa Yogendra.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = Dr. Hansa Yogendra | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pronunciation = | birth_name = Hansa Patni | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1947|10|08}} | birth_place = [[Indore]], [[Madhya Pradesh]], India | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | residence = [[Mumbai]], India | nationality = Indian | other_names = | citizenship = | education = [[Bachelor of Science|BSc.]], [[Bachelor of Laws|LLB]] | alma_mater = [[Mithibai College]]
[[Government Law College, Mumbai]] | occupation = Yoga Guru, Author, Researcher & Director of [[The Yoga Institute]] | years_active = | era = | employer = | organization = [[The Yoga Institute]] | agent = | known_for = [[Yoga]] | notable_works = | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = ''Yoga for Better Living'' on [[DD National]] (1980)
''Yoga Sutra'' on [[Zee TV]] | title = President of [[The Yoga Institute]] | term = February 2018-present | predecessor = [[Jayadeva Yogendra]] | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = [[Jayadeva Yogendra]] | partner = | children = Hrishi Yogendra | parents = | mother = Tara Patni | father = Jitendra Phulchand Patni | relatives = | family = [[Yogendra|Shri Yogendra]] (father-in-law) | callsign = | awards = | website = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''Dr. Hansa Yogendra''' (born 1947) is an Indian yoga guru, author and researcher and TV personality.{{cite book|author1=P. Warden|title=Parsiana, Volume 17|date=1994|publisher=the [[University of Virginia]]|page=34}}{{cite book|title=India Today International, Volume 26|date=2001|publisher=[[Living Media]], the [[University of Michigan]]|page=59}}{{cite news |title=Taarak Mehta fame Disha Vakani seeks the blessing of Smt. Hansaji, writes a moving post |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/tv/news/hindi/taarak-mehta-fame-disha-vakani-seeks-the-blessing-of-smt-hansaji-writes-a-moving-post/articleshow/63592711.cms?slideshow=63285703&slide=63285704#10 |publisher=[[The Times of India]] |date=April 3, 2018}} She is director of [[Mumbai]] based [[The Yoga Institute]], a government recognized non-profit organization and the oldest organized yoga center in the world, founded in 1918.{{cite news|last1=Mishra|first1=Debashree|title=Once Upon A Time: From 1918, this Yoga institute has been teaching generations, creating history|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/cities/mumbai/once-upon-a-time-from-1918-this-yoga-institute-has-been-teaching-generations-creating-history/|publisher=[[Indian Express]]|date=July 3, 2016}} She was TV presenter of the television series ''Yoga for Better Living'', aired on [[DD National]] in 1980s.{{cite news|last1=Guha|first1=Kunal|title=Relative value: A century of wellness|url=https://mumbaimirror.indiatimes.com/others/sunday-read/relative-value-a-century-of-wellness/articleshow/62398932.cms|publisher=[[Mumbai Mirror]]|date=January 7, 2018}} She is chairperson of Yoga Certification Committee for [[Quality Council of India]] (QCI){{cite web|title=Compostion of The Yoga Certification Committee of QCI|url=http://yogacertification.qci.org.in/pdf/YOGA%20CERTIFICATION%20COMMITTEE%20.pdf|website=yogacertification.qci.org.in|publisher=[[Quality Council of India]]}} and President of International Board of Yoga.{{cite news|last1=Mishra|first1=Vimal|title=बिन गुरु सधे न योग...|url=http://epaper.navbharattimes.com/details/49796-7470-2.html|publisher=[[Navbharat Times]]|date=June 14, 2015|location=Mumbai|language=Hindi}} She also serves as Vice President of the Indian Yoga Association. == Early life == Born on October 8, 1947 to Jitendra Phulchand Patni and Tara Patni, in a [[Jain]] family. She completed her graduation in science from [[Mithibai College]]. Later, she complete her Yoga teacher training course at [[The Yoga Institute]]. She also holds a degree in Law from the [[Government Law College, Mumbai]]. She received a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D]]. from The Open International University for Complimentary Medicines in February 2018.{{cite news |title=Dr. Hansaji Jayadeva Yogendra: On The Meaning of Life |url=https://excellencereporter.com/2018/04/24/dr-hansaji-jayadeva-yogendra-on-the-meaning-of-life/ |publisher=Excellencereporter |date=April 24, 2018}} == Works == [[File:Hansa Yogendra, Baba Ramdev, Swami Chidanand Saraswati Ji.jpg|thumb|250px|Dr. Hansa Yogendra, [[Chidanand Saraswati]] and [[Ramdev|Baba Ramdev]] at the International Yoga Festival 2018, in [[Rishikesh]]]] In 1991, She was invited by the [[National Council of Educational Research and Training]] along with [[Jayadeva Yogendra]] to advise on formulating a Yoga education syllabus for schools in India. She has conducted several seminars and lecture tours in [[India]] and in [[Canada]], [[Pakistan]], [[Europe]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Australia]] and [[United States Of Amerca|USA]].{{cite journal|title=Yogi of the Month|journal=Yoga Life International|date=April 2015|volume=Vol. 1|issue=Issue.2|pages=7|url=http://www.yogalife.co.in/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/UYLSnewsletter_2nd_Issue_PDF.pdf|publisher=Ujjain Yoga Life Society}} === Bibliography === * ''Yoga Daily Planner - Heart Care'', (1990) {{ISBN|978-8185053318}} * ''Yogic Life-Cure of Asthma and Bronchitis'', (1992) {{ISBN|978-8185053325}} * ''Pregnancy, Parenthood and Yoga'', (1991) {{ISBN| 978-8185053257}} * ''Dincharya'', (1997) * ''Yoga for Back and Joint disorders'', (1997) {{ISBN|978-8185053363}} * ''Recipes For Happiness:Yogic lifestyle diet'', (2002) {{ISBN|978-8185053561}} * ''Recipes for Happiness'', (2001) {{ISBN|978-81-85053-56-1}} * ''Yogic Life-Control of Diabetes'', (1992) {{ISBN|81-85053-33-2}} * ''Yoga of Caring'', (1997) {{ISBN|978-8185053370}} * ''Thoughts on the Gita'' {{ISBN|9788185053493}} * ''Marriage A Spiritual Journey'', (2010) {{ISBN|978-81-85053-80-6}} * ''Insights through Yoga'', (2000) {{ISBN| 978-8185053530}} * ''Swadhaya Practical Tips—For self-development'', (2007) {{ISBN|978-81-85053-78-3}} * ''Yoga for the Police'', (2011) {{ISBN|978-81-85053-82-0}} * ''Yoga for the Police - Tanmanachya Swasthya Sathi'', (2011) {{ISBN|978-81-85053-82-0}} * ''Yoga of Caring'', (2015) {{ISBN|978-93-84670-04-7}} * ''Inspiration'', (2003) * ''Yoga Sutra of Patanjali'', (2009) {{ISBN|978-81-85053-79-0}} * ''How to Reverse Heart Disease the Yogic Way-Research, Facts and Program'', (2004) {{ISBN|978-8185053660}} * ''Values of Life'', (2005) {{ISBN|978-81-85053-76-9}} * ''Growing with Yoga '', (2008) {{ISBN| 978-8185053448}} == Personal life == She married to [[Jayadeva Yogendra]]{{cite news|last1=Guha|first1=Kunal|title=Prominent yoga guru passes away|url=https://mumbaimirror.indiatimes.com/mumbai/other/prominent-yoga-guru-passes-away/articleshow/62954387.cms|publisher=[[Mumbai Mirror]]|date=February 17, 2018}} in 1973. She is daughter-in-law of [[Yogendra|Shri Yogendra]].{{cite news|last1=Jhangiani|first1=Diipti|title=Neighbourhood Haven The Yoga Institute|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/mumbai/report-neighbourhood-haven-the-yoga-institute-1923076|publisher=[[DNA India]]|date=November 22, 2013}}{{cite book|author1=Mark Singleton|author2=Ellen Goldberg|authorlink1=Mark Singleton (writer)|title=Gurus of Modern Yoga|date=2013|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|isbn=9780199938728|page=73}} == Awards & recognition == * Vocational Excellence Award by [[Rotary Club|Rotary Club of Bombay]] in 1994. * Recognized for her contribution to Women's Health through the award presented by Society for the Promotion of Area Resource Centres –SPARC. * Special Award by The International Association of Yoga Therapists for pioneering work in [[Yoga Therapy]], Yoga education and research in 2011. * Awarded with ''Yoga Tapaswini'' title at Pune International Yoga Week. * Award of Excellence by [[Podar International School]] for her contribution in the field of Yoga ducation. * She was conferred with Special Award by [[Lions Clubs International]] on June 21, 2015. * Invited as the [[Keynote]] speaker at International Conference on Yoga for Holistic Health at [[Vigyan Bhawan]], New Delhi on the topic of Contribution of Yoga for World Peace on June 2, 2015. * Rotary International Award 2017 by the [[Rotary International]] for her contribution to spread the awareness of Yoga at the Annual Rotary International District conference; at Hotel Sahara Star, Mumbai. * She was honored with a [[Lifetime Achievement Award]] in 2017 for being an ambassador of yoga for peace and harmony, at the Annual [[Rotary International]] District conference; at Hotel Sahara Star, Mumbai. * Invited as a chief guest who spoke on the 'qualities of yoga teacher' at Pune International Yoga Festival on January 6, 2018, held at Chinmaya Vibhooti Ashram, Pune. * Vocational Excellence Award by Rotary Discon Utsav Award 2018 at Rotary Utsav, on February 4, 2018. * She received a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D]]. from The Open International University for Complimentary Medicines in February 2018. * [[Swami Chidanand Saraswati]] conferred the ''Divine Shakti Leadership Award'' to Dr. Hansa Yogendra on [[International Women's Day]] 2018 at [[Parmarth Niketan]], International Yoga Festival. == Further reading == * {{cite book|title=Das Schweizer Buch: bibliographisches Bulletin der Schweizerischen Landesbibliothek, Bern|date=2003|publisher=Schweizerischer Buchhändler- und Verlegerverein, [[Indiana University]]|page=329|language=German}} * {{cite book|author1=Subba Rao|title=The Call of Yoga : The Life And Mission Of Dr. Jayadeva & Hansaji Yogendra|date=January 2018|publisher=Zen Publications|isbn=9789385902918|url=https://www.flipkart.com/call-yoga-life-mission-dr-jayadeva-hansaji-yogendra/p/itmffzc4vwbdmceu?gclid=Cj0KCQjw3InYBRCLARIsAG6bfMS9GELu2OPSF_SmzCUowXmDxzKa3ZaTGAnpch76hRHpraIlgcXIWIcaAsXPEALw_wcB&pid=9789385902918&lid=LSTBOK9789385902918JVOTZ3&tgi=sem%2C1%2CG%2C11214002%2Cg%2Csearch%2C%2C170219493259%2C1o1%2C%2C%2Cc%2C%2C%2C%2C%2C%2C%2C&s_kwcid=AL%21739%213%21170219493259%21%21%21g%21295092701166%21&ef_id=Wlu7cgAABfyg%40BFC%3A20180521162017%3As}} * {{cite book|author1=Anne Cushman|author2=Jerry Jones|title=From here to nirvana: the essential guide to the yogis and gurus, ashrams and temples of spiritual India|date=February 4, 1999|publisher=[[Rider (imprint)]]|isbn=9780712670616}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tPqVXk1kyyU Yog Satra with Yogachrya Hansa Jaidev Yogendra] on ''[[DD News]]'' (Interview) * [http://theyogainstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/Slide11.jpg One has to keep in mind the self] on ''DayBreak'' (October 25, 1997) * [http://theyogainstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/LOKMAT-1024x720.jpg योग ही जगण्याची कला] on ''[[Lokmat]]'' (Marathi) * [http://theyogainstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/Navbharat-Times-mumbai1_June-2015-1024x718.jpg योग है जीवन जीने का विज्ञान] on ''[[Navbharat Times]]'' {{Portal bar|Biography|Spirituality|Yoga}} page.title: International Charter of Physical Education, Physical Activity and Sport

revision.comment: /* CIGEPS */Apply [[WP:AWB/GF|Gen fix(es)]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: four year → four-year
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=November 2015}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox treaty | name = International Charter of Physical Education, Physical Activity and Sport | long_name = | image = UNESCO logo English.svg | image_width = | caption = | type = [[International Charter]] | date_drafted = 04 November 2014 | date_effective = 18 November 2015 | date_signed = | location_signed = {{Flag|France}}，[[Paris]] | date_sealed = | condition_effective = | date_expiration = | signatories = | parties = | depositor = [[UNESCO]] | language = | languages = Arabic, Chinese, English, French, Russian, and Spanish | footnotes= http://www.unesco.org/new/en/social-and-human-sciences/themes/physical-education-and-sport/sport-charter/ | wikisource = }} The '''International Charter of Physical Education, Physical Activity and Sport'''<ref>{{cite web|url= http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0023/002354/235409e.pdf |title= International Charter of Physical Education, Physical Activity and Sport | date=18 November 2015 |accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref> is a [[rights-based]] document which was adopted by member states of the [[United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization]] (UNESCO), on November 18, 2015 during the 38th session of the UNESCO General Conference. This document is the legitimate successor of the '''International Charter of Physical Education and Sport''',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID=13150&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html |title=International Charter of Physical Education and Sport | date=21 November 1978 |accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref> originally adopted in 1978, during the 20th General Conference of UNESCO.
The original Charter, which was amended in 1991, was the first rights-based document to state that '''“the practice of physical education and sport is a fundamental right for all”'''. Based on the universal spirit of the original Charter (1978), and integrating the significant evolutions in the field of sport over the last 37 years, the revised Sport Charter highlights the health benefits of physical activity, the inclusion of persons with disabilities, the protection of children, the role of sport for development and peace, as well as the need to protect the integrity of sport from doping, violence, manipulation and corruption.
== Objectives ==
In twelve brief articles, the revised Charter serves as a universal reference on the ethical and quality standards of physical education, physical activity and sport. While preserving the initial intention of the 1978 Charter, this new document also represents a renewed commitment of the international sports community to actively promote sport as a catalyst for peace and development.
The revised version of the Sport Charter provides a framework that orients the protection of the integrity of sport and supports broader policies in favour of grassroots sport. It also recognizes physical education as a driver for promoting gender equality, social inclusion, non-discrimination and sustained dialogue in our societies.
UNESCO Director-General, [[Irina Bokova]] said: “The adoption of the revised Charter should mark a shift away from words towards action, from policy intent to implementation. It sets the tone for a new international sport policy debate, which should now focus on the exchange of good practice, education and training programmes, capacity development, and advocacy. This is also a strong recognition of physical education as a driver for promoting gender equality, social inclusion, non-discrimination and sustained dialogue in our societies.” <ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.unesco.org/new/en/media-services/single-view/news/international_charter_of_physical_education_revised_to_ensure_more_inclusive_access_to_physical_activity/#.VlL51tHlvs0 |title= Press release issued by UNESCO to announce the adoption of the Sport Charter | date=18 November 2015 |accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref>
== Contents == The International Charter of Physical Education, Physical Activity and Sport contains a preamble and 12 articles. These are the main values defended by the Charter:
=== Access to sport as a fundamental right for all === Article 1 - The practice of physical education, physical activity and sport is a fundamental right for all
=== The values and benefits of sport === Article 2 - Physical education, physical activity and sport can yield a wide range of benefits to individuals, communities and society at large
Article 11 - Physical education, physical activity and sport can play an important role in the realization of development, peace and post-conflict and post-disaster objectives
=== Quality and ethical principles === Article 4 - Physical education, physical activity and sport programmes must inspire lifelong participation.
Article 5 – All stakeholders must ensure that their activities are economically, socially and environmentally sustainable.
Article 6 - Research, evidence and evaluation are indispensable components for the development of physical education, physical activity and sport.
Article 7 - Teaching, coaching and administration of physical education, physical activity and sport must be performed by qualified personnel.
Article 8 - Adequate and safe spaces, facilities and equipment are essential to quality physical education, physical activity and sport.
Article 9 - Safety and the management of risk are necessary conditions of quality provision.
Article 10 - Protection and promotion of the integrity and ethical values of physical education, physical activity and sport must be a constant concern for all
=== The roles of different stakeholders === Article 3 – All stakeholders must participate in creating a strategic vision, identifying policy potions and priorities.
Article 12 – International cooperation is a prerequisite for enhancing the scope and impact of physical education, physical activity and sport.
== Applications == The [[Quality Physical Education Policy Project]]<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.unesco.org/new/en/social-and-human-sciences/themes/physical-education-and-sport/policy-project/ |title= Quality Physical Education Policy Project |accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref> illustrates how principles and recommendations stipulated in the Charter can be translated into indicators, benchmarks and tools.
== Authors of the Revision == The revision of the Charter involved experts and practitioners from governments, sports organizations, academia and NGOs. This new version was carefully examined through sessions of the '''Intergovernmental Committee for Physical Education and Sport (CIGEPS)''' and its '''Permanent Consultative Council (PCC'''), as well as UNESCO’s '''Executive Board'''. It is a follow-up to the '''Declaration of Berlin'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/social-and-human-sciences/themes/physical-education-and-sport/mineps-2013/declaration/|title= Declaration of Berlin| date=30 May 2013 |accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref> that was adopted by 600 participants from 121 countries, as an outcome of the '''5th World Conference of Sport Ministers (MINEPS V)'''.
=== MINEPS === Created in 1976, the [[International Conference of Ministers and Senior Officials Responsible for Physical Education and Sport]] (MINEPS) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/social-and-human-sciences/themes/physical-education-and-sport/mineps/ |title=The International Conference of Ministers and Senior Officials Responsible for Physical Education and Sport (MINEPS) |accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref> is a forum that facilitates intellectual and technical exchange in the field of physical education and sport. MINEPS also serves as an institutional mechanism for a coherent international strategy in this domain. It is also the only global platform that engages governments, intergovernmental organizations, the sport movement, academia and specialized NGOs.
=== CIGEPS === The [[Intergovernmental Committee for Physical Education and Sport]] (CIGEPS) <ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.unesco.org/new/en/social-and-human-sciences/themes/physical-education-and-sport/cigeps/ |title= The Intergovernmental Committee for Physical Education and Sport (CIGEPS) |accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref> was established in 1978 to promote the role and value of sport and its inclusion in public policy. CIGEPS is composed of expert representatives in the field of physical education and sport from 18 UNESCO Member States, each elected for a four-year term. In 2015, CIGEPS is composed of the 18 following member states of UNESCO: {{columns-list|colwidth=22em| *{{flag|Azerbaijan}} *{{flag|Brazil}} *{{flag|Colombia}} *{{flag|Congo}} *{{flag|Denmark}} *{{flag|Germany}} *{{flag|Indonesia}} *{{flag|Iran}} *{{flag|Madagascar}} *{{flag|Malaysia}} *{{flag|Mexico}} *{{flag|Oman}} *{{flag|Qatar}} *{{flag|Russia}} *{{flag|South Africa}} *{{flag|Turkey}} *{{flag|Ukraine}} *{{flag|Yemen}} }}
===Permanent Consultative Council === The Permanent Consultative Council (PCC), comprising key sport federations, UN agencies and NGOs, provides technical support and advice to the CIGEPS. {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[International Council of Sport Science and Physical Education]] (ICSSPE) * [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) * [[International Paralympic Committee]] (IPC) * [[SportAccord]] * [[United Nations Children’s Fund]] (UNICEF) * [[United Nations Development Programme]] (UNDP) * [[United Nations Environment Programme]] (UNEP) * [[United Nations Global Compact|United Nations Global Compact Office]] * [[United Nations Office on Sport for Development and Peace]] (UNOSDP) * [[UN Women]] * [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) * [[Association of National Olympic Committees]] (ANOC) * [[Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] (FIFA) * [[Fédération Internationale de Natation]] (FINA) * [[International University Sports Federation|Fédération Internationale du Sport Universitaire]] (FISU) * [[Havas|Havas Sports and Entertainment]] * [[Institut de Relations Internationales et Stratégiques]] (IRIS) <ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.iris-france.org/ |title= Institut de Relations Internationales et Stratégiques |accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref> * [[International Association of Athletic Federations]] (IAAF) * [[International Biathlon Union]] (IBU) * [[International Fair Play Committee]] * [[International Pierre de Coubertin Committee]] <ref>{{cite web|url= http://coubertin.org/ |title= International Pierre de Coubertin Committee |accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref> * [[International Working Group on Women and Sport]] <ref>{{cite web|url= http://iwg-gti.org/ |title= International Working Group on Women and Sport |accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref> * [[Peace and Sport |Peace and Sport Organization]] * [[PL4Y International]] <ref>{{cite web|url= http://pl4y.international/fr |title= PL4Y International |accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref> * [[Play the Game (NGO)]] * [[Right to Play]] * [[TAFISA|The Association for International Sport for All]] (TAFISA) * [[World Anti-Doping Agency]] (WADA) * [[World Federation of the Sporting Goods Industry]] (WFSGI) <ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.wfsgi.org/ |title= World Federation of the Sporting Goods Industry |accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref> }}
== References == {{Reflist|1}}

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Historical organisations based in the Republic of Ireland to [[:Category:History organisations based in the Republic of Ireland]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=October 2018}}
The '''Irish Georgian Society''' aims to encourage an interest in and to promote the conservation of distinguished examples of architecture and the allied arts of all periods in Ireland. These aims are achieved by education and grants, planning participation, membership and fundraising.
==Achievements==
Notable achievements of the Irish Georgian Society include, among others, the saving of threatened great buildings such as [[Castletown House]], County Kildare; [[Roscrea Castle|Damer House]], County Tipperary; Doneraile Court, County Cork; Roundwood, Co. Laois; Tailors’ Hall, Dublin and 13 Henrietta Street, Dublin.
Recent projects include the restoration of mid-eighteenth century panelled rooms at Ledwithstown, County Longford; the repair of the early nineteenth-century south tower roof at Barmeath Castle, Co. Louth; the restoration of the pavilion cupolas of Kilshannig, Co. Cork, built in the 1760s to the designs of the Italian architect [[Davis Ducart]]; and, in association with the Department of the Environment, Heritage & Local Government, the World Monuments Fund and the Headfort Trust, the restoration of the superb Robert Adam decorative schemes at Headfort, County Meath.
These conservation efforts are funded by the members’ participation in the Society’s events programme, the fundraising of our chapters, by donations and bequests and by sales from the Society’s online book and gift shop.
The current project (2011- ) is the restoration of Dublin's 1760s City Assembly House in South William Street. This was the first purpose-built public exhibition gallery in Britain or Ireland.<ref>http://www.openhousedublin.com/index.php/tour/city-assembly-house/</ref> From 1809 it was the debating chamber of [[Dublin Corporation]] for nearly a century, and was the scene of many famous speeches by [[Daniel O'Connell]].
==Membership== The Society is a membership organisation whose purpose is to promote awareness and the protection of Ireland's architectural heritage and decorative arts. The Society was founded in 1958 by the Hon. [[Desmond Guinness]] and his late wife Mariga and since that time many buildings of significant architectural merit have been saved through their work and the work of members and supporters. The next President of the Society was [[Desmond FitzGerald, 29th Knight of Glin]], who died in 2011, followed by [[Patrick Guinness]].<ref> Ronald Porter, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/desmond-fitzgerald-last-of-the-knights-of-glin-and-champion-of-irelands-heritage-2369621.html "Desmond Fitzgerald: Last of the Knights of Glin and champion of Ireland's heritage"], Independent, October 2011 </ref>
In 2006 the Hon. Desmond Guinness was awarded a [[Europa Nostra]] prize for the Society's preservation activities.
==50th anniversary== A fully illustrated book by Robert O'Byrne on the society's first 50 years was published in 2008.<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/dp/1906429022 The Georgian Society Celebration]</ref>
==Events== In June 2015 a summer school is planned, with the [[Ulster Architectural Heritage Society]], entitled Conservation without frontiers: Historic buildings of Armagh and Monaghan in context.<ref>{{cite web|title=UAHS & IGS Summer School Open For Booking Now|url=http://www.uahs.org.uk/news/?q=0&article=194|website=Ulster Architectural Heritage Society|accessdate=30 April 2015}}</ref>
==Support from the USA and UK== Much of the Society's income comes from supporters outside Ireland. In the USA they were registered in 1968 as Irish Georgian Society Inc., and in the UK as the "Irish Georgian Trust".<ref>http://www.charitiestrust.org/charities/IrishGeorgianTrust/index.html</ref> The Society's work within the [[Republic of Ireland]] is managed by the Irish-registered Irish Georgian Foundation, registered in 1970.<ref>http://www.cro.ie/search/CompanyDetails.aspx?id=32176&type=C</ref>
== See also == * [[Georgian Dublin]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.igs.ie Official site] *[http://igscork.blogspot.com IGS Cork Chapter Blog] *[http://sources.nli.ie/Search/Results?lookfor=&filter%5b%5d=periodical_title:%22Quarterly%20bulletin%20of%20the%20Irish%20Georgian%20Society%22 Index to articles in the "Quarterly bulletin of the Irish Georgian Society"]
[[Category:Georgian architecture in Ireland]] [[Category:Heritage organizations]] [[Category:History organisations based in the Republic of Ireland]]
